title: General Paper FQE (Aug 2021)
description: Final Qualifying Examination General Paper from August 2021. Contains 49 questions covering Nursing Education, Mental Health, Pediatrics, Research, and Professionalism.

questions.question: Arrange the levels of the Affective Domain (Bloom's Taxonomy) in the correct sequence from lowest to highest:
questions.explanation: The correct hierarchy of the Affective Domain is Receiving -> Responding -> Valuing -> Organization -> Characterization.

questions.question: The affective domain of learning primarily emphasizes:

options.text: The development of motor skills and attitudes
The intellectual abilities of remembering and reasoning
The employment of attitudes and values

questions.explanation: The affective domain deals with emotions, feelings, values, appreciation, motivations, and attitudes. Option B describes the Cognitive domain.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding teaching strategies are FALSE? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Guidance has no role in evaluation in teaching
Demonstration is the best method in teaching attitude
Guidance plays a role in formative evaluation
Role play is effective for teaching attitudes

questions.explanation: Guidance IS important in evaluation (feedback). Demonstration is best for skills, not attitudes (Attitudes are best taught via role play/modeling). Therefore, statements A and B are False.

questions.question: As a principle of teaching, individualization means:

options.text: Engaging the learners individually in tuition to accommodate slow learners
Varying teaching methods to accommodate each learner's speed and compatibility
The teacher should teach the subject alone
Giving feedback to an individual learner for confidentiality

questions.explanation: Individualization involves adapting methods to meet diverse learner needs, styles, and paces.

questions.question: Reinforcement of positive behavior should effectively be done:

options.text: When the person who did well asks

questions.explanation: Immediate reinforcement strengthens the association between the behavior and the reward.

questions.question: The sum total of all learning activities and experiences a learner undertakes in a learning institution from admission till qualifying is referred to as:
questions.explanation: Curriculum encompasses the totality of student experiences (planned and unplanned). Syllabus is just the content list.

questions.question: Methods of teaching attitude include:
questions.explanation: Attitudes are best taught via experiential and social methods (Role play, Discussion). Lectures are generally ineffective for changing attitudes.

questions.question: The appropriate approach a teacher should use when teaching adults is:
questions.explanation: Andragogy (Knowles) is the art and science of helping adults learn. Pedagogy is for children.

questions.question: A lesson plan is useful because:

options.text: Students are able to use it during classes
It enables the teacher to be systematic in his/her presentation
It is a blue print of teaching problems identified by the teacher
It provides guidelines on curriculum issues

questions.explanation: A lesson plan serves as a roadmap for the instructor, ensuring systematic flow and time management.

questions.question: In relation to assessment of skills, OSCE stands for:
questions.explanation: OSCE is the standard acronym for Objective Structured Clinical Examination.

questions.question: Hospitals established by Dorothea Dix were designed to provide which of the following?
questions.explanation: Dorothea Dix advocated for humane treatment, leading to the establishment of Asylums (places of refuge).

questions.question: Psychiatric rehabilitation focuses primarily on:
questions.explanation: The recovery model emphasizes building upon the client's existing strengths and abilities.

questions.question: The client belief that news broadcasts have special meaning for him or her is an example of:
questions.explanation: Ideas of reference involve the false belief that irrelevant occurrences relate directly to oneself.

questions.question: The state in which the patient repeats words or phrases spoken by another is:
questions.explanation: Echolalia is the parrot-like repetition of words. Echopraxia is repetition of movements.

questions.question: Misinterpretation of an external stimuli is referred to as:
questions.explanation: An illusion is a false perception of a real external stimulus.

questions.question: Causes of organic mental illness include:
questions.explanation: Organic disorders have demonstrable physical causes (Trauma, Infection, Toxicity). Stress is functional.

questions.question: The legal document/form filled during emergency admission of a mental patient in Kenya is:
questions.explanation: MOH 613 is used for involuntary/emergency psychiatric admissions.

questions.question: Which of the following contains an atypical antipsychotic drug?
questions.explanation: Risperidone and Clozapine are atypical (2nd gen). Chlorpromazine and Haloperidol are conventional (1st gen). Option A lists one of each.

questions.question: The nurse teaches a psychiatric client about Benztropine. This drug is administered to:
questions.explanation: Benztropine (Cogentin) is an anticholinergic used to treat Extrapyramidal Side Effects (EPS).

questions.question: A state that is progressive to permanent intellectual impairment due to organic change in the brain is:
questions.explanation: Dementia is chronic, progressive, and often permanent. Delirium is acute and reversible.

questions.question: Classification of severe dehydration in a child includes which signs?

options.text: Lethargy, sunken eyes, inability to drink
Restlessness, eager to drink, sunken eyes
Skin pinch goes back slowly, irritable, eager to drink water
Sunken eyes, ability to drink, irritable

questions.explanation: Severe Dehydration signs (IMCI): Lethargic/Unconscious, Sunken eyes, Unable to drink, Skin pinch goes back very slowly.

questions.question: The most appropriate management of a child with severe malnutrition who is in a state of shock includes:

options.text: High protein diet, Intravenous fluids, Warmth
Intravenous fluids, high calorie diet, Antibiotic

questions.explanation: In severe malnutrition with shock, cautious IV fluids are indicated alongside antibiotics and sugar.

questions.question: Cleft palate in an infant born at term is best repaired at the age of:
questions.explanation: Cleft palate repair is typically done between 9-18 months. Cleft lip is repaired earlier (3 months).

questions.question: The conditions associated with cataract in children are:
questions.explanation: Congenital Rubella Syndrome is a classic cause of congenital cataracts.

questions.question: The nurse will question an order of lumbar puncture for a child with:
questions.explanation: Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in raised ICP due to the risk of brain herniation.

questions.question: The priority nursing intervention for a 4 year old brought to casualty convulsing is:

options.text: Confirm whether the child is breathing and give oxygen
Check for airway obstruction and place in lateral position

questions.explanation: Priority is Airway and Safety. Placing in lateral/recovery position prevents aspiration.

questions.question: The nursing care for a child with advanced cystic fibrosis will include:

options.text: Providing postural drainage after meals at bedtime

questions.explanation: Enzymes are given WITH meals. Postural drainage is BEFORE meals. Skin care is generally appropriate.

questions.question: When performing physical examination on a 2-year-old, the nurse will:

options.text: Carefully explain all procedures at this time
Begin with the least intrusive procedure
Proceed in a head to toe examination
Ask the parent to leave the room

questions.explanation: For toddlers, start with non-threatening areas and do intrusive exams (ears/mouth) last.

questions.question: In emergency triage and treatment (ETAT) of children, emergency signs include:

options.text: Tiny child below 3 months, referral case
Severe dehydration, vomiting, lower limb oedema

questions.explanation: Convulsions, Obstructed breathing/Cyanosis, and Coma are Emergency signs. 'Vomiting everything' is a danger sign but grouped here in C which has 2 definitive emergency signs.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about research methodologies is TRUE?

options.text: In qualitative research, information is mainly collected without formal structured instruments
In quantitative research, the investigator participates in the event under study
Quantitative research uses snowball sampling primarily

questions.explanation: Qualitative research uses flexible, unstructured tools. Quantitative investigators aim for objectivity/detachment.

questions.question: The degree of consistence with which an instrument yields similar results is:
questions.explanation: Reliability refers to consistency/stability of the measure.

questions.question: The main difference between experimental and non-experimental studies in research is that:

options.text: The researcher is a passive observer in an experimental study
The researcher manipulates the independent variable in non-experimental study
The researcher is an active participant/agent in experimental study
The researcher manipulates the dependent variable in experimental study

questions.explanation: In experiments, the researcher actively manipulates the independent variable (intervention).

questions.question: The term 'editing' in data processing refers to:

options.text: Assigning numerals or other symbols to answers
Reducing a large volume of data into homogeneous group
Examining the collected raw data to detect errors and omissions
Arranging assembled data into concise and logical order

questions.explanation: Editing involves cleaning raw data to ensure completeness and accuracy.

questions.question: The main purpose of publishing research findings is to:

options.text: Meet the requirement of the sponsor
Solicit for more funds for future research

questions.explanation: Contribution to the body of knowledge (literature) is the primary scientific goal.

questions.question: The type of research that focusses on finding a solution to an immediate clinical problem is termed as:
questions.explanation: Applied research aims to solve practical, immediate problems.

questions.question: Hawthorne effect in research means:

options.text: People behave differently when they know they are being observed
The researchers getting involved in the activities they are observing
The first impression created by the researcher towards the subjects
The ability to produce same results using same circumstances

questions.explanation: Hawthorne effect is behavior modification due to awareness of observation.

questions.question: In research, probability sampling involves selection of:

options.text: Individual at regular intervals from sampling frame
Categories of study units such that a certain number appears in the sample
Procedures to ensure that each unit of the sample is chosen on the basic of chance

questions.explanation: Probability sampling gives every member a known, non-zero chance of selection.

questions.question: Calculate the mean in the following sample values: 3, 8, 6, 14, 0, -4, 0, 12, -7, 0, -10
questions.explanation: Sum of values is 22. Count is 11. Mean = 22/11 = 2.

questions.question: The demerits of longitudinal research include:

options.text: It is more effective, more information will be collected
It is more expensive, more time is required
Large sample can be covered, less dropout rate
More time is required, more information will be collected

questions.explanation: Longitudinal studies are costly, time-consuming, and suffer from high attrition.

questions.question: The period in the trends of psychiatry characterized by passing of laws to protect mentally ill persons is:
questions.explanation: The Political (Legislative) period involved enacting laws for patient protection.

questions.question: State SIX factors that influence teaching and learning.
Outline FIVE advantages of a problem-based learning curriculum.
State FIVE benefits of stating learning outcomes in a lesson plan.
State FIVE roles of a mental health nurse in fighting social stigma.
Outline FIVE features of obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD).
State FIVE sources of research problems.
Outline FIVE signs and symptoms of a child with Cushing's syndrome.
Outline FOUR benefits of Integrated Management of Childhood Illness (IMCI) strategy.
Nursing Professionalism: Select correct Codes, Characteristics, Principles, and Patient Rights.
